name: (5Z)-3-{[(4-nitrophenyl)amino]methyl}-5-[(4-nitrophenyl)methylidene]-2-thioxo-1,3-thiazolidin-4-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1092

name: (5Z)-3-{[(4-nitrophenyl)amino]methyl}-5-[(4-nitrophenyl)methylidene]-2-thioxo-1,3-thiazolidin-4-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1092
Reason: The target compound has several structural features to consider for predicting the melting point: a thiazolidinone core, nitro substituents, and anilino (phenylamino) groups. - Basic unit (thiazolidinone structure) is estimated to have a moderate melting point due to its five-membered ring with heteroatoms providing some degree of rigidity: ~120°C. - Nitro groups: Two nitro groups are present, and each contributes significantly to the melting point by introducing strong intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions and possibly hydrogen bonding. Estimated increase per nitro group: +30°C. - Anilino groups: While the aniline itself tends to lower the melting point due to its ability to donate hydrogen bonds, when attached to a structure, it can increase the melting point due to stacking interactions and increased molecular rigidity. Estimated increase: +5°C per anilino group. Considering these effects, a cumulative addition to the base thiazolidinone structure melting point estimate is made.
Prediction: The predicted melting point is therefore approximately 120 (thiazolidinone base) + 30 (first nitro group) + 30 (second nitro group) + 5 (first anilino group) + 5 (second anilino group), which totals to a predicted melting point of 190°C.
